div.p: X M L - eXtensible Markup Language - is one of the representational "glue" technologies for building webapps, particularly distributed ones.
It provides a rich data structure, validation and transformation tools, and is the underlying data representation for many internet accessible services.
XML provides conventions for marking up text to denote a tree-like structure of nested values, each of which might also have attributes.
There is an example-xml Github repository with sample XML data.
HTML and XML came from the same roots, and appear very similar to each other.
HTML uses a pre-defined set of allowed element names, and attributes for many of the elements.
XHTML is in between HTML and XML, but still closer to HTML.
XML adds semantic meaning.

HTML excerpt:

Customer: George

XHTML excerpt:

Customer: George>/p>
XML excerpt: <customer>George</customer>
These excerpts come from "order" files inside the orders folder in the examples repo.
There is an HTML standard, but the browser developers have chosen to extend it, with vendor-specific attributes and with different liberal interpretation of closing element tags.
Not an issue with XML, which addresses data representaiton and not presentation.
Html excerpt which "deals" with IE: <!--[if IE]> <marquee>Jim's Rockin' Joint</marquee> <![endif]-->
To be fair, HTML has evolved so that most vendor-specific stuff is handled through CSS, per the CSS spec or per "CSS hacks". The HTML *can be* relatively clean.
Most CSS frameworks require that HTML pages make extensive use of the class or id attributes, attached to webpage elements.
The browser result looks good, but the CSS additions to the HTML don't add to the semantic value :(
XML supports a rich, tree-like model for data.
Data relationships that would require separate tables in the RDB world can be managed through a single XML document.
An RDB solution for our order...
The RDB solution might be more cryptic if customer and item codes were used instead of names...
It sounds like XML has some attraction for data representation.
But wait, there are many ways to structure an XML document to represent the same data :(
An XML document could be attribute-centric...

pre.code: <order id="12346" customer="Andre" date="20161109-1335PST"> <item code="burger" qty="1" price="5.00"/> <item code="fries" qty="1" size="medium" price="2.00"/> </order>

div.p: Or an XML document could be element-centric...
And, of course, it could be anything in between.

slide.title: 2. CONSTRAINING XML DATA
slide.p: XML suits data representation better than HTML, because of the structure and element names, that add semantic meaning or intent.
An XML document is "well-formed" if it satisfies a few rules:

ul.li: all elements have a matching closing tag or are self-closing
all elements are strictly properly nested

slide.p: An XML document is "valid" if it is well-formed and conforms to a constraining document. Two types of these are document type definitions and schemas.

div.p: A Document Type Definition (DTD) can be used to constrain the structure and some simple content constraints for an XML document. In the example repo, order-dtd.xml is meant to be validated against order.dtd.
One way to validate is inside your server-side code...

pre.code:
<!ELEMENT order (customer,date,total,details)> <!ATTLIST order id CDATA #REQUIRED>
<!ELEMENT customer (#PCDATA)> <!ELEMENT date (#PCDATA)> <!ELEMENT total (#PCDATA)>
<!ELEMENT details (item)*> <!ELEMENT item EMPTY> <!ATTLIST item code CDATA #IMPLIED qty CDATA #IMPLIED price CDATA #IMPLIED size CDATA #IMPLIED >

slide.title: DTD Shortcomings
slide.p: DTDs are simple, and have been around for years, but are far from perfect:

ul.li: minimal element cardinality (none, one or some)
can be over-ridden by internal DTD subset

div.p: A Schema can be used to constrain the structure and some relatively complex constraints for an XML document. In the example repo, order-schema.xml is meant to be validated against order.xsd.
Schemas are very powerful, but very complicated. An excerpt is shown to the right, but I will talk to the slide during lecture.
We will address validation next week!

slide.title: Schema Shortcomings
slide.p: XML Schemas are more complex than DTDs, but more powerful. They have been around for years too, and were at the height of their popularity during the Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP) ascendency, in the 2000s.

ul.li: enumerated attribute values, more flexible than DTDs

slide.title: 3. XML STRATEGIES
slide.p: The opening slide for this lesson showed "Magic" between a client and a server. XML *isn't* that magic, but it is used for data representation within much of that "Magic".

slide.title: XML as the Payload
slide.p: Many services use XML formatted data structures as the payload of an HTTP message.

ul.li: Cisco IP phone services (weather, news, etc)

slide.title: XML as Payload Wrapper
slide.p: Many services use XML formatted data wrapper structures, to hold the payload of a service request or response.

slide.title: XML for Configuration
slide.p: Many services use XML formatted configuration files, eliminating the need for an RDB.

slide.title: 4. XML TOOLS
slide.p: There are a number of tools common in the XML world...

ul.li: Extensible stylesheets (XSL) can be used to transform XML data, for instance into HTML for reporting
Formatting Object Processors (FOP) take specially formatted XSL output and create PDF documents
Enterprise Service Bus is an integration architecture, with support for a number of services
XPath is a specification for traversing Document Object Models (DOMs), with packages implemented for most programming languages
Its DOM model and processing have become mainstream patterns
